dialogue:
Doctor: What brings you in today?
Patient: I've had a sore throat for 3 days, hurts when swallowing.
Doctor: Fever?
Patient: 100.4 yesterday.
Doctor: Cough or congestion?
Patient: Slight congestion, no cough.
Doctor: Sick contacts?
Patient: My sister had a cold last week.
soap:
S: Patient reports 3-day history of sore throat worsened by swallowing, mild congestion, and subjective fever up to 100.4°F. Recent sick contact with sister who had a cold.
O: Mild fever reported, no cough. No airway difficulty or systemic symptoms mentioned.
A: Likely viral pharyngitis. Differentials: streptococcal pharyngitis, allergic rhinitis.
P: Recommend hydration, NSAIDs for pain/fever, throat lozenges, rest. Return if fever persists >3 days, difficulty breathing, drooling, or worsening pain.

dialogue:
Patient: My left eye keeps twitching randomly.
Doctor: How long has this been happening?
Patient: About two weeks. Mostly when I'm stressed or tired.
Doctor: Any vision changes?
Patient: No, vision is normal.
Doctor: Caffeine intake?
Patient: 4 coffees a day.
soap:
S: Patient reports 2-week history of intermittent left eyelid twitching, triggered by stress and fatigue. Denies visual changes.
O: No reported neurological deficits or visual disturbance.
A: Likely eyelid myokymia. Differentials: electrolyte imbalance, benign essential blepharospasm.
P: Reduce caffeine intake, improve sleep hygiene, monitor symptoms. Return if twitching spreads, vision changes, or weakness develops.

dialogue:
Doctor: Tell me about the headaches.
Patient: Started 6 months ago, pressure behind my eyes.
Doctor: Frequency?
Patient: 3–4 times a week.
Doctor: Triggers?
Patient: Screens and stress.
Doctor: Any nausea or vision changes?
Patient: No.
soap:
S: Patient reports 6-month history of headaches 3–4 times weekly, described as pressure behind the eyes, triggered by screen exposure and stress. No associated nausea or visual changes.
O: No reported neurological deficits or red-flag symptoms.
A: Likely tension-type headache. Differentials: migraine without aura, sinus headache.
P: Recommend screen breaks, hydration, stress management, NSAIDs as needed. Consider headache diary. Follow-up if worsening or neurological symptoms develop.

dialogue:
Patient: I've been coughing for a week.
Doctor: Dry or productive?
Patient: Dry.
Doctor: Fever?
Patient: None.
Doctor: Shortness of breath?
Patient: No.
Doctor: Smoking history?
Patient: Never.
soap:
S: Patient reports 1-week history of dry cough without fever or dyspnea. No smoking history.
O: No systemic symptoms or respiratory distress noted.
A: Likely post-viral cough. Differentials: allergic cough, GERD-related cough.
P: Reassurance, hydration, honey/lozenges, avoid irritants. Return if cough lasts >3 weeks, fever, or breathing difficulty develops.

dialogue:
Doctor: What brings you in?
Patient: My right knee hurts when I climb stairs.
Doctor: When did it start?
Patient: About a month ago.
Doctor: Trauma?
Patient: No injury.
Doctor: Swelling?
Patient: Mild after long walks.
soap:
S: Patient reports 1-month history of right knee pain aggravated by stairs and prolonged walking, with mild swelling. No trauma.
O: No instability, locking, or systemic symptoms reported.
A: Suspected patellofemoral pain syndrome. Differentials: early osteoarthritis, meniscal irritation.
P: Recommend activity modification, NSAIDs as needed, quadriceps strengthening, ice after activity. Follow-up if worsening.

dialogue:
Patient: I feel short of breath when exercising.
Doctor: How long has this been happening?
Patient: About 2 months.
Doctor: Chest pain?
Patient: No.
Doctor: Smoking?
Patient: No.
Doctor: Asthma history?
Patient: Had mild asthma as a kid.
soap:
S: Patient reports 2-month history of exertional shortness of breath. No chest pain. Childhood history of mild asthma.
O: No acute respiratory distress reported.
A: Possible exercise-induced bronchoconstriction. Differentials: deconditioning, anemia.
P: Recommend spirometry, trial short-acting bronchodilator before exercise, assess fitness level, follow-up after testing.

dialogue:
Doctor: What happened?
Patient: I twisted my ankle yesterday while running.
Doctor: Able to walk?
Patient: Yes, but painful.
Doctor: Swelling?
Patient: A little.
soap:
S: Patient reports acute right ankle pain after twisting injury yesterday, able to bear weight with discomfort, mild swelling present.
O: No numbness, weakness, or deformity reported.
A: Likely lateral ankle sprain. Differentials: fracture, tendon strain.
P: RICE therapy, NSAIDs, gradual weight bearing, consider X-ray if pain persists or inability to walk develops.

dialogue:
Patient: My stomach burns after eating spicy food.
Doctor: How long?
Patient: 3 weeks.
Doctor: Nausea or vomiting?
Patient: No.
Doctor: Alcohol?
Patient: Occasionally.
soap:
S: Patient reports 3-week history of burning epigastric discomfort after spicy meals. No nausea or vomiting.
O: No alarming GI symptoms reported.
A: Likely gastritis or acid reflux. Differentials: peptic ulcer disease, functional dyspepsia.
P: Avoid triggers, trial antacid/PPI, limit alcohol, follow-up if persistent or worsening.

dialogue:
Doctor: What's going on?
Patient: I'm exhausted all the time.
Doctor: How long?
Patient: About 2 months.
Doctor: Sleep?
Patient: 5 hours a night.
Doctor: Diet?
Patient: Mostly takeout.
soap:
S: Patient reports 2-month history of persistent fatigue, sleeping 5 hours nightly, poor diet. No other associated symptoms mentioned.
O: No reported weight loss, fever, or neurological symptoms.
A: Suspected inadequate sleep and nutrition. Differentials: anemia, hypothyroidism.
P: Improve sleep hygiene, balanced diet, consider CBC and TSH screening. Follow-up in 4 weeks.

dialogue:
Patient: My back hurts after long hours at my desk.
Doctor: Duration?
Patient: 4 months.
Doctor: Radiation down legs?
Patient: No.
Doctor: Exercise?
Patient: Rarely.
soap:
S: Patient reports 4-month history of low back pain associated with prolonged sitting. Denies leg numbness or radiation.
O: No neurological deficits reported.
A: Likely mechanical low back pain. Differentials: muscle strain, early degenerative disc disease.
P: Recommend posture correction, stretching, ergonomic adjustments, NSAIDs as needed, gradual exercise program.

dialogue:
Doctor: Why are you here today?
Patient: My heart sometimes feels like it's skipping a beat.
Doctor: How often?
Patient: A few times a day for the past week.
Doctor: Chest pain?
Patient: No.
Doctor: Caffeine?
Patient: Energy drinks daily.
soap:
S: Patient reports 1-week history of intermittent palpitations occurring several times daily, associated with frequent energy drink consumption. Denies chest pain.
O: No syncope, dizziness, or dyspnea reported.
A: Suspected benign premature beats. Differentials: electrolyte imbalance, supraventricular ectopy.
P: Reduce caffeine intake, hydration, consider ECG if persistent. Return sooner if chest pain, fainting, or worsening symptoms.

dialogue:
Patient: My skin gets itchy after hot showers.
Doctor: Any rash?
Patient: Slight redness.
Doctor: New soaps or detergents?
Patient: No.
Doctor: History of eczema?
Patient: Yes, mild as a kid.
soap:
S: Patient reports itchiness and mild redness after hot showers. History of childhood eczema.
O: No open lesions or systemic symptoms reported.
A: Likely xerotic dermatitis. Differentials: mild eczema flare, contact dermatitis.
P: Recommend lukewarm showers, fragrance-free moisturizer, avoid irritants. Consider topical steroid if persistent.

dialogue:
Doctor: Tell me about the dizziness.
Patient: Happens when I stand up fast.
Doctor: How long?
Patient: 3 weeks.
Doctor: Fainting?
Patient: No.
soap:
S: Patient reports 3-week history of dizziness upon standing, brief duration, no syncope.
O: No chest pain, palpitations, or neurological deficits reported.
A: Likely orthostatic lightheadedness. Differentials: dehydration, anemia.
P: Increase fluids, rise slowly from sitting, consider BP check and CBC if persistent.

dialogue:
Patient: My ears feel clogged.
Doctor: Pain?
Patient: No.
Doctor: Hearing loss?
Patient: Slight.
Doctor: Swimming?
Patient: Yes, daily.
soap:
S: Patient reports clogged ears with mild hearing decrease, recent frequent swimming. No pain.
O: No fever or discharge reported.
A: Possible cerumen impaction or otitis externa. Differentials: eustachian tube dysfunction.
P: Recommend ear exam, avoid Q-tips, consider ear drops if external irritation present.

dialogue:
Doctor: What seems to be the issue?
Patient: My hands shake when I'm anxious.
Doctor: Resting tremor?
Patient: No, only when nervous.
Doctor: Caffeine?
Patient: 3 cups daily.
soap:
S: Patient reports intermittent hand tremors during anxiety-provoking situations. No resting tremor. Moderate caffeine intake.
O: No neurological deficits reported.
A: Likely physiologic tremor triggered by anxiety. Differentials: caffeine-related tremor, essential tremor.
P: Reduce caffeine, stress management, monitor symptoms. Follow-up if persistent or worsening.
